head.title: Metro Business; Work Starting for Plant

hedline.hl1: Metro Business; Work Starting for Plant

abstract.p: New York State officials say work will start soon on $8 million project to improve truck and rail access to Outokumpu Copper Americas, major industrial plant in Buffalo; work is final step in two-year, state-aided effort to help operation remain viable and increase its 860-employee work force (S)

block.p: Work is to start soon on an $8 million project to improve truck and rail access to a major industrial plant in Buffalo. The work is the final step in a two-year, state-aided effort to help the operation remain viable and increase its 860-employee work force, New York State officials say.

The plant, run by Outokumpu Copper Americas, which makes copper and brass products, has been involved in a $15 million program to upgrade its machinery and to add equipment to manufacture a new line of parts used in connectors for electrical wiring in products ranging from cars to computers.

Work is to start soon on an $8 million project to improve truck and rail access to a major industrial plant in Buffalo. The work is the final step in a two-year, state-aided effort to help the operation remain viable and increase its 860-employee work force, New York State officials say.

The plant, run by Outokumpu Copper Americas, which makes copper and brass products, has been involved in a $15 million program to upgrade its machinery and to add equipment to manufacture a new line of parts used in connectors for electrical wiring in products ranging from cars to computers.

The state's Department of Transportation has agreed to finance $2.4 million of the cost of the road and rail improvements, and the Empire State Development Corporation has provided $500,000 in grants to help finance the plant's upgrading and to train workers to use the new machinery, officials said.
